{{redirect|Seram|the village in Nepal|Seram, Nepal}} {{Infobox Islands |name = Seram Island |image_name = Seram en.png |image_caption = Seram Island |map_image = Maluku Islands en.png |map_caption = |native_name = |native_name_link = |location = [[Oceania]] |coordinates= |archipelago = [[Molucca Islands]] |total_islands = |major_islands = |area_km2 = 17100 |rank = 52nd |highest_mount = [[Mount Binaiya|Binaiya]] |elevation_m = 3027 |country = [[Indonesia]] |country_admin_divisions_title =Province |country_admin_divisions =[[Maluku (province)|Maluku]] |country_largest_city = |country_largest_city_population = |country_1 = |country_1_admin_divisions_title = |country_1_admin_divisions = |country_1_largest_city = |country_1_largest_city_population = |country_2 = |country_2_admin_divisions_title = |country_2_admin_divisions = |country_2_largest_city = |country_2_largest_city_population = |population = 434,113 |population_as_of = 2010 | density_km2 = 25.4 |ethnic_groups = [[Manusela people|Manusela]], [[Nuaulu]] |country_admin_divisions_title_1=Regencies|country_admin_divisions_1=[[Central Maluku Regency|Central Maluku]], [[East Seram Regency|East Seram]], [[West Seram Regency|West Seram]]|timezone1=[[Time in Indonesia|IEST]]|utc_offset1=+09:00}}
'''Seram''' (formerly spelled '''Ceram'''; also '''Seran''' or '''Serang''') is the largest and main [[island]] of [[Maluku (province)|Maluku]] [[Provinces of Indonesia|province]] of [[Indonesia]], despite [[Ambon Island]]'s historical importance. It is located just north of smaller Ambon Island and a few other surrounding islands, such as [[Haruku Island|Haruku]], [[Geser Island|Geser]], [[Nusalaut]], [[Banda Islands|Banda]] and [[Saparua]].
== Geography and geology == Seram is traversed by a central [[mountain range]], the highest point of which, [[Mount Binaiya]], is covered with dense [[rain forest]]s. Its remarkably complex geology is because of its location at the meeting of several tectonic microplates, which has been described as "one of the most tectonically complex areas on Earth".<ref name=Cooper>{{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Ian|title=Seram Geology|url=http://www.ee.usyd.edu.au/suss/Bulls/37(2)/seramgeology.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020106064535/http://www.ee.usyd.edu.au/suss/Bulls/37(2)/seramgeology.html|archivedate=January 6, 2002}}</ref> Seram actually falls on its own microplate, which has been twisted around by 80° in the last 8 million years<ref name=Linthout1994>{{cite journal|last=Linthout|first=Kees|author2=Hendrik Helmers |title=Pliocene obducted, rotated and migrated ultramafic rocks and obduction-induced anatectic granite, SW Seram and Ambon, Eastern Indonesia|journal=Journal of Southeast Asian Earth Sciences|date=January–February 1994|volume=9|issue=1-2|pages=95–109|doi=10.1016/0743-9547(94)90068-X}}</ref> by the relatively faster movement of the Papua microplate. Meanwhile, along with the northward push of the Australian Plate, this has resulted in the uplift that gives north-central Seram peaks of over 3000 m. On the island are important karst areas. In the mountains near Sawai is the cave Hatu Saka, currently the deepest cave in Indonesia (-388 m). In Taniwell district, on the north coast, is the underground river [[Sapalewa River|Sapalewa]], one of the largest underground rivers on the planet.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Seram 2012|url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/294548575/Seram-2012|website = Scribd|accessdate = 2016-01-05}}</ref><ref>https://www.scribd.com/doc/294386822/Seram-2015</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/358966666/Seram-Speleologia-76-2016|title=Seram Speleologia 76 2016|website=Scribd|language=en|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
The population of the island in the 2010 Census was 434,113 people, administered among 3 regencies, [[Central Maluku Regency|Maluku Tengah Regency]] had 170,392 people on Seram Island itself<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sp2010.bps.go.id/files/ebook/8103.pdf |title=Hasil Sensus Penduduk 2010 : Agregat Data per Kecamatan |publisher=Sp2010.bps.go.id |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> and 191,306 on the lesser islands (majority on Ambon Island), the entirety of [[West Seram Regency|Seram Bagian Barat Regency]] and [[East Seram Regency|Seram Bagian Timur Regency]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bps.go.id/aboutus.php?sp=0&kota=81 |title=Statistics Indonesia |publisher=Bps.go.id |accessdate=2013-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061014/http://www.bps.go.id/aboutus.php?sp=0&kota=81 |archivedate=2013-09-21 |df= }}</ref>
== Ecology== Seram Island is remarkable for its high degree of localised bird endemism.<ref name="Birdlife">[[BirdLife International]]: [http://www.birdlife.org/action/science/species/asia_strategy/pdf_downloads/forestsFO8.pdf Saving Asia's threatened birds] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130093951/http://birdlife.org/action/science/species/asia_strategy/pdf_downloads/forestsFO8.pdf |date=2010-11-30 }}, 2003, retrieved 19 May 2010</ref> From the 117 species of [[birds]] on the island, 14 are [[Endemism in birds|endemic]], including the [[eclectus parrot]], [[purple-naped lory]], [[salmon-crested cockatoo]], [[Seram masked owl]], [[lazuli kingfisher]], [[sacred kingfisher]], [[grey-necked friarbird]] and [[Moluccan king parrot]].<ref name="dephut">[http://www.dephut.go.id/INFORMASI/TN%20INDO-ENGLISH/manusela_NP.htm Inonesian Ministry of Forestry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226161226/http://www.dephut.go.id/INFORMASI/TN%20INDO-ENGLISH/manusela_NP.htm |date=2010-12-26 }}, retrieved 19 May 2010</ref>
The mammals found on Seram include Asian species ([[Muridae|murid rodents]]) as well as Australasian [[marsupial]]s. The montane area of Seram supports the greatest number of endemic mammals of any island in the region. It harbors 38 mammal species and includes nine species that are endemic or near endemic, several of which are limited to montane habitats. These include the [[Seram bandicoot]], [[Pteropus chrysoproctus|Moluccan flying fox]], [[Ceram fruit bat|Seram flying-fox]], [[Manusela mosaic-tailed rat]], [[spiny Ceram rat]] and the [[Ceram rat]], all considered threatened.<ref name="WWF">{{WWF ecoregion|id=aa0118|name=Seram rain forests|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref>
[[Saltwater crocodile]]s exist within some of the island's rivers, including the [[Salawai River]].
In the eastern part of the island, [[Manusela National Park]] has been established in 1997, covering an area of 1,890 km² (11% of the island).<ref name="dephut"/>
== History == [[File:AMH-4719-NA The fort at Loki and Company troops in the interior.jpg|thumb|Dutch fort at [[Loki, Indonesia|Loki]] and [[Dutch East India Company|Company]] troops in the interior, c. 1652]]
Most central Moluccans consider Seram to be their original ancestral home and it is still known colloquially as Nusa Ina (Mother Island).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ema-huaresi.com/homepage.htm |title=Homepage Ema - Huaresi Rehung |publisher=Ema-huaresi.com |accessdate=2013-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921060751/http://www.ema-huaresi.com/homepage.htm |archivedate=2013-09-21 |df= }}</ref><ref>''Lonely Planet Indonesia'' 7th Edition, page 840</ref> In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, Seram was generally within the sphere of influence of [[Ternate]], although it was often ruled more directly by the Ternaten vassal state of [[Buru]]. The expedition of [[António de Abreu]] (as captain) and [[Francisco Serrão]] sighted and explored the entire southern coast of Seram in early 1512, for the first time for Europeans.<ref>{{cite book|first=Armando|last=Cortesão|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h82D-Y0E3TwC&lpg=PR81&dq=Simao%20Afonso%20Bisagudo&pg=PR81#v=onepage&q=Simao%20Afonso%20Bisagudo&f=false|title=The Suma Oriental of Tomé Pires: an account of the east, from the Red Sea to Japan, written in Malacca and India in 1512–1515/The Book of Francisco Rodrigues rutter of a voyage in the Red Sea, nautical rules, almanack and maps, written and drawn in the east before 1515|publisher=The [[Hakluyt Society]]|year=1944}}</ref> [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[missionaries]] were active there in the 16th century. [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[trading post]]s were opened in the early 17th century, and the island came under nominal Dutch control c. 1650. In the 1780s, Seram provided a key base of support for [[Prince Nuku]] of [[Tidore]]'s long-running rebellion against Dutch rule. From 1954 until 1962 the island's mountain terrain was the scene of an armed guerilla struggle against Indonesian rule by the counter revolutionary [[Republic of South Moluccas]] movement led by [[Soumokil]].
== Administration == Seram includes three of the [[Regency (Indonesia)|regencies]] within the province of Maluku. [[West Seram Regency|West Seram]] (Kabupaten Seram Bagian Barat), capital at Dataran Hunipopu, had a population (2003) of 140,657; and [[East Seram Regency|Eastern Seram]] (Kabupaten Seram Bagian Timur), capital at Dataran Hunimoa, had a population (2003) of 78,336. The [[Central Maluku Regency]] (Kabupaten Maluku Tengah), with its capital at [[Masohi]], includes the middle part of Ceram, as well as some other smaller islands.
== Religion == [[File:Tulehu.png|thumb|250px|View from a boat towards Tulehu, on the North Seram coast]] Seram has been traditionally associated with the [[Animist|animism]] of the indigenous [[Alfur]] (or [[Nuaulu]]), a West Melanesian people who reputedly retained a custom of headhunting until the 1940s.<ref>Lonely Planet Indonesia, 8th edition p762</ref> Today, however, most of the population of Seram today is either [[Muslim]] or [[Christian]] due to both conversion and immigration. Seram was affected by the violent inter-religious conflict that swept Maluku province starting in late 1998, resulting in tens of thousands of displaced persons across the province<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/ambon/amron-01.htm |title=Indonesia |publisher=Hrw.org |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref> but after the [[Malino II Accord]] agreement tempers cooled. Seram has been peaceful for many years but towns like Masohi remain informally divided into de facto Christian and Muslim sections. Around 7,000 people belonging to the [[Manusela people|Manusela]] tribe follow Hinduism.<ref>Note: the Indonesia definition of Hinduism is a complex legal matter; in effect Hinduism was a supercategory used to define non Islamic and Christian religions hence any pagan style religion. This is not to say that it is not related to Hinduism at its root, however.</ref>
== Economy == [[Copra]], [[resin]], [[sago]], and [[fish]] are important products. [[Oil]] is produced in the northeast near Bula by CITIC Seram Energy<ref name=citic>{{cite web|title=Oil|url=http://www.citicresources.com/eng/business/oil.htm#Seram|work=Seram Non-Bula Block, Indonesia|publisher=CITIC Resources Holdings Limited|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419154526/http://www.citicresources.com/eng/business/oil.htm#Seram|archivedate=2013-04-19|df=}}</ref> who took over from KUFPEC (Indonesia) Limited in 2006.<ref>[http://www.kufpec.com/KUFPEC/en-US/Operations/SouthEastAsia/Indonesia/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309121644/http://www.kufpec.com/KUFPEC/en-US/Operations/SouthEastAsia/Indonesia/ |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref> The Oseil oil field is located onshore in the northeast of the island in the Seram Non-Bula Production Sharing Contract area.<ref name=citic/> The discovery well was drilled in 1993.<ref name=citic/> As of end 2010 the Seram Non-Bula Block had estimated proven oil reserves of 9.7 million barrels.<ref name=citic/> Most production comes from the Jurassic Manusela carbonate formation.<ref name=hu>{{cite web|title=The application of seismic anisotropy technology in fractured carbonate reservoir|url=http://www.ldocean.com.cn/Upload/Download/File78.pdf|work=73rd EAGE Conference & Exhibition|publisher=LandOcean Energy Services|author=Hu xueyan|date=May 2011}}</ref><ref name=le>{{cite web|title=Seram (non-Bula) projects|url=http://www.lionenergy.com.au/projects2.htm|publisher=Lion Energy Limited|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830082335/http://www.lionenergy.com.au/projects2.htm|archivedate=2007-08-30|df=}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Sigurd Ferdinand Olson | image = Sigurd F. Olson.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = April 4, 1899 | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1982|1|13|1899|4|4}} | death_place = | nationality = | alma mater = [[Northland College (Wisconsin)|Northland College]]
[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]
[[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]] | other_names = | spouse = Elizabeth Dorothy Uhrenholdt | known_for = | notable works = ''The Singing Wilderness'' | awards = [[John Burroughs Medal]] (1974) | occupation = Teacher, [[nature writing|nature writer]], President of [[The Wilderness Society (United States)|The Wilderness Society]] (1963–1971) }} '''Sigurd Ferdinand Olson''' (April 4, 1899 – January 13, 1982) was an [[United States|American]] author, [[environmentalism|environmentalist]], and advocate for the protection of [[wilderness]]. For more than thirty years, he served as a wilderness guide in the lakes and forests of the [[Boundary Waters|Quetico-Superior country]] of northern [[Minnesota]] and northwestern [[Ontario]]. He was known honorifically as ''the Bourgeois'' — a term the [[Voyageurs|voyageur]]s of old used of their trusted leaders. ==Biography== Born in [[Chicago, Illinois]] to [[Swedish American|Swedish]] [[Baptists|Baptist]] parents, Olson grew up in northern [[Wisconsin]] where he developed his lifelong interest in the outdoors. They moved first to Sister Bay, then Prentice, then Ashland. In June 1921, Olson took his first canoe trip where he fell in love with the canoe country wilderness of northern [[Minnesota]] that would become the [[Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness]] (with his help).Minnesota Historical Society ''SIGURD F. OLSON: An Inventory of His Papers at the Minnesota Historical Society'' & ''Biographical Note - Chronology'' Retrieved 10/28/13 http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00316.xml His first article, an account of a canoe expedition, was published by the Milwaukee Journal on July 31, 1921. In August of that year, Olson married Elizabeth Dorothy Uhrenholdt, and the two spent their honeymoon on another canoe trip in the Boundary Waters. He worked as a canoe guide for J.C. Russell's outfitters on Fall Lake in [[Winton, Minnesota]], before purchasing the business in 1929. He led canoe expeditions for a group that became known as the "Voyageurs," which routinely included [[Eric W. Morse]], [[Denis Coolican]], Blair Fraser, Tony Lovink, Eric W. Morse, Elliott Rodger, and [[Omond Solandt]]. After studying [[agriculture]], [[botany]], [[geology]], and [[ecology]] at [[Northland College (Wisconsin)|Northland College]], the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], and the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]], Olson moved to [[Ely, Minnesota]] to teach biology at Ely Junior College (now [[Vermilion Community College]]). He later chaired the science department and served as dean. in 1947 he resigned from his teaching position and began writing full-time. He spent most of his life in the Ely area, working as a [[canoe]] guide during the summer months, teaching, and writing about the [[natural history]], [[ecology]], and outdoor life in and around the Boundary Waters. On August 27, 1971, a little over a year after the celebration of the first [[Earth Day]], [[Northland College (Wisconsin)|Northland College]] hosted its first environmental conference. Among those invited to address the two-day conference were Senator [[Gaylord Nelson]] and Sigurd Olson. The conference became "the instrument of origin of the [[Sigurd Olson Environmental Institute]]," as [[Robert Matteson]], the founder of the Institute, wrote. With energy to move in a new and exciting direction, and guided by the philosophies of Sigurd Olson, the Institute opened its doors in spring of 1972, embarking on more than 30 years of serving Northland College and the [[Lake Superior]] region. In 1974, Olson earned the [[John Burroughs Medal]], the highest honor in nature writing. He died on January 13, 1982 of a heart attack while snowshoeing near his home.{{cite news|title=Sigurd Olson, a Writer And Environmentalist|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/15/obituaries/sigurd-olson-a-writer-and-environmentalist.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 15, 1982}} He received a tribute from the US Senate on the 100th anniversary of his birth.http://www4.uwm.edu/letsci/research/sigurd_olson/tribute.htm ''U.S. Senate Tribute to Sigurd Olson'' August 3, 1999 Page S10134. Retrieved 1/19/14 ==Preservation work== Olson was influential in the protection of the [[Boundary Waters]] and helped draft the [[Wilderness Act]] of 1964, becoming vice-president of [[The Wilderness Society (United States)|The Wilderness Society]] from 1963 to 1967 and President 1968 to 1971. He also helped establish [[Voyageurs National Park]] in northern Minnesota, Alaska's [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]], and [[Point Reyes National Seashore]] in California. Sigurd also was a consultant to the Secretary of the Interior [[Stewart Udall]] on wilderness and national park issues. After over 50 years of hard work, Sigurd reached his goal. Full wilderness status was granted to the [[Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness]] by [[Jimmy Carter]] in 1978, four years before Sigurd died. His hard work was commemorated in many different ways, including in the naming of a central building of YMCA [[Camp Widjiwagan]], located on nearby Burntside Lake. Olson was President of the [[National Parks Conservation Association|National Parks Association]] and a member of its Board of Trustees. ==List of works== * ''The Singing Wilderness'' (1956) * ''Listening Point'' (1958) * ''The Lonely Land'' (1961) * ''Runes of the North'' (1963) * ''Open Horizons'' (1969) * ''The Hidden Forest'' (1969) * ''Wilderness Days'' (1972) * ''Reflections From the North Country'' (1976) * ''Of Time and Place'' (1982) * ''Songs of the North''. Howard Frank Mosher, ed. (1987) * ''The Collected Works of Sigurd F. Olson: The Early Writings, 1921-1934''. Mike Link, ed. (1988) * ''The Collected Works of Sigurd F. Olson: The College Years, 1935-1944''. Mike Link, ed. (1990) * ''The Meaning of Wilderness: Essential Articles and Speeches''. Edited and with an Introduction by [[David Backes (author)|David Backes]]. (2001) * ''Spirit of the North: The Quotable Sigurd F. Olson''. Edited and with an Introduction by [[David Backes (author)|David Backes]]. (2004) ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Backes, David. ''A Wilderness Within: The Life Of Sigurd F. Olson''. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1997. ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://listeningpointfoundation.org/ Listening Point Foundation] - a non-profit organization dedicated to furthering Sigurd Olson's legacy * [http://www.northland.edu/soei/ The Sigurd Olson Environmental Institute] at Northland College * Sigurd Olson [https://www4.uwm.edu/letsci/research/sigurd_olson/contents.htm website at the University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee] * Sigurd Olson at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20041212092705/http://people.mnhs.org/authors/biog_detail.cfm?PersonID=Olso153 Minnesota Historical Society's Author Biography Project] *The [http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00316.xml Sigurd Olson Papers] are available for research use at the [http://www.mnhs.org Minnesota Historical Society.] {{The Wilderness Society}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olson, Sigurd F.}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:American environmentalists]] [[Category:American conservationists]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Northland College (Wisconsin) alumni]] [[Category:University of Illinois alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Chicago]] [[Category:Writers from Minnesota]] [[Category:Writers from Wisconsin]] [[Category:American people of Swedish descent]] [[Category:People from St. Louis County, Minnesota]] [[Category:John Burroughs Medal recipients]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:American nature writers]] [[Category:Sierra Club awardees]]

The '''Southern African Bird Atlas Project''' (SABAP) was conducted between 1987 and 1991.<ref name="ASAB">Harrison, J.A., Allan, D.G., Underhill, L.G., Herrmans, M., Tree, A.J., Parker, V. & Brown, C.J. (1997) ''The Atlas of Southern African Birds. Vols 1 and 2'', BirdLife South Africa, Johannesburg, South Africa</ref> Because a new bird atlas was started in southern Africa in 2007, the earlier project is now referred to as SABAP1. The new atlas project is known as the Second Southern African Bird Atlas Project, and is abbreviated to [[SABAP2]].
SABAP covered six countries: [[Botswana]], [[Lesotho]], [[Namibia]], [[South Africa]], [[Swaziland]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. At the time, [[Mozambique]] was engulfed in a [[civil war]], and had to be excluded. The resolution for SABAP1 was the quarter degree grid cell ([[QDGC]]), 15 minutes of latitude by 15 minutes of longitude, 27.4 km north-south and about 25 km east-west, an area of about 700 km². However, in Botswana a half degree grid cell was used. The total number of grid cells, taking account of the coarser resolution in Botswana, was 3973. Fieldwork was conducted mainly in the five-year period 1987–1991, but the project coordinators included all suitable data collected from 1980–1987. In some areas, particularly those that were remote and inaccessible, data collection continued until 1993.
Fieldwork was undertaken mainly by birders, and most of it was done on a volunteer basis. Fieldwork consisted of compiling bird lists for the QDGCs. All the checklists were fully captured into a database. The final dataset consisted of 147 605 checklists, containing a total of 7.3 million records of bird distribution. Of the total 3973 QDGCs, only 88 had no checklists (2.2% of the total).<ref name="ADU">{{cite web|url=http://www.adu.org.za/pdf/SABAP1_Introduction.pdf |format=PDF |title=THE ATLAS OF SOUTHERN AFRICAN BIRD : VOLUME 1: NON-PASSERINES |website=Adu.org.za |accessdate=2016-12-02}}</ref>
Project coordination was undertaken by the Avian Demography Unit (ADU) at the [[University of Cape Town]]. The unit changed its name in 2008 to [[Animal Demography Unit]], to reflect its expanding ambit, but retained the acronym ADU.
The final product of the project was a two-volume set of A4-sized books, covering 932 species, with a total of 1500 pages, published in 1997 by [[BirdLife South Africa]].<ref name="ASAB" /> The books are now out of print, but the individual species texts are available on the [[SABAP2]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sabap2.adu.org.za |title=SABAP2 | Welcome to the Southern African Bird Atlas Project |website=Sabap2.adu.org.za |date= |accessdate=2016-12-02}}</ref> Volume 1 also contains a chapter on the relevance of southern African geography to birds.<ref name="ADU"/> ''The Atlas of Southern African Birds'' was, at the time of publication, the largest biodiversity project ever conducted in Africa. This project showed that birdlife in southern Africa reflects the wide diversity of habitats in the region: 9% of the world's bird species are regularly found there, even though it constitutes only 1.67% of the world's land area.<ref name="ASAB" />
The impact of the project on southern African ornithology was considerable. The species texts did not only provide information on distribution, but also presented new information and analyses on the seasonality of breeding and the direction and seasonality of migration. SABAP therefore became an essential reference for all research involving these fundamental aspects of avian biology.<ref>Harrison, J.A., Underhill, L.G. & Barnard, P. 2008. The seminal legacy of the Southern African Bird Atlas Project. South African Journal of Science 102: 82–84</ref> It provided much of the information upon which the [[Important Bird Area]] selection process in southern Africa was based,<ref>Barnes, K.N. (ed.) 1998. The Important Bird Areas of Southern Africa. BirdLife South Africa, Johannesburg.</ref> and for the [[IUCN Red List]] for birds in South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland.<ref>Barnes, K.N. (ed.) 2000. The Eskom Red Data Book of Birds in South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. BirdLife South Africa, Johannesburg.</ref>

page.title: State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (Azerbaijan)

revision.comment: /* Investments */Fixing [[WP:CHECKWIKI]] #16: unicode contol character (and other minor general edits caused by AWB), replaced: →
revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources |nativename = Alternativ və Bərpa Olunan Enerji Mənbələri üzrə Dövlət Agentliyi |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = Coat of arms of Azerbaijan.svg |seal_width = 120px |seal_caption = Coat of Arms of Azerbaijan |formed = July 16, 2009 |date1 = |date1_name = |date2 = |date2_name = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = 40 Uzeyir Hajibeyov Street, [[Government House, Baku|Government House]], Gate IV, [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan Republic]] AZ1000 |latd = |latm = |lats = |latNS = |longd = |longm = |longs = |longEW = |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = [[Akim Badalov]] |chief1_position =
Director of the State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.area.gov.az www.area.gov.az] |footnotes = }} The '''State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources, SAARES''' ({{lang-az|Alternativ və Bərpa Olunan Enerji Mənbələri üzrə Dövlət Agentliyi, ABEMDA}}) is a [[governmental agency]] under the [[Ministry of Industry and Energy (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Industry and Energy]] mandated by the Cabinet of Ministers.{{cite web | url= http://area.gov.az/ | title= Official website of the State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources}} It serves as the principal regulatory institution in the sphere of alternative and renewable energy in the [[Azerbaijan|Republic of Azerbaijan]]. The State Agency is headed by [[Akim Badalov]]. ==History== The State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (SAARES) was established following a [[President of Azerbaijan|Presidential]] Decree in July 16, 2009{{Cite news|url=https://www.azernews.az/business/89152.html|title=Germany to support wind energy development in Azerbaijan|date=2015-10-28|work=AzerNews.az|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://azerbaijans.com/content_1740_en.html|title=Renewable energy in Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=azerbaijans.com|language=az|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-30}} as a part of the [[Ministry of Industry and Energy (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Industry and Energy]].{{cite web | url= http://archive.president.az/articles.php?item_id=20090716064638302&sec_id=29 | title= Official website of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan |accessdate=2011-05-23}} The main purpose is to provide the country with alternative sources of energy. Before the foundation of the Agency, there was “State Program on alternative and renewable energy sources in the Republic of Azerbaijan” approved by Decree No 462 of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan in October, 2004. According to the Decree of the President of Azerbaijan Republic [[Ilham Aliyev]] in 2012 the agency was liquidated and instead the State Company on Azerbaijan Republic on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (ABEMDA) was founded. == State programs == In 2011 President Ilham Aliyev planned a second government strategy on alternative and renewable energy sources for the years 2012-2020. Targets according to strategy: * a reduction in [[Greenhouse gas|greenhouse gas emissions]] of at least 20% below 1990 levels; * 20% of energy consumption to come from renewable resources; * an increase in energy efficiency by 20% by 2020. The State Program on Use of Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources in Azerbaijan Republic: * To determine potential of alternative and renewable energy in the electricity power generation; * To increase the efficiency of utilization of energy resources through attracting exploitation of renewable energy; * To provide additional job places by creating new energy production facilities; * To increase energy capacity and achieve energy security in Azerbaijan Republic.{{Cite web|url=https://unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/energy/se/pp/eneff/7th_IFESD_Baku_Oct.2016/8_path/Malikov_Azerbaijan.pdf|title=State programs on use of alternative and renewable energy in Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Structure== The agency is headed by its director [[Akim Badalov]] and it resides in the [[Government House, Baku|Government House]] in [[Baku]]. ==Duties== The Agency has the mandate of the principal regulatory institution in the sphere of [[Alternative energy|alternative]] and [[renewable energy]] and is tasked with assessment of sustainable energy potential, shaping relevant policies, including tariff policy, elaboration and enforcement of relevant procedures such as issue of special permissions to the public and private entities to construct power generation facilities. == Function of ABEMDA == * preparation of state policy, legal acts, regulatory documents * implementation of state policy for creation and development of the relevant sphere and infrastructure * preparation the offers for using of energy sources in relevant areas, projecting of objects, its construction, maintenance and regulation mechanism of activities related to manufacture of equipment necessary for these purposes; * Monitoring the implementation of the activity in the relevant field. ==Current Projects== In spring 2011, SAARES in cooperation with [[United Nations Development Programme|UNDP]] launched a new project on ‘Promoting Development of Sustainable Energy in Azerbaijan’. This project became possible with the financial support of €500,000 provided by the [[European Commission]] and $790,000 contributed by the Government of [[Norway]]. Azerbaijan’s energy production is currently largely reliant on the exploitation of the country’s hydrocarbon reserves and while the development of renewable energy is one of the government’s strategic priorities, the legal and institutional environment are not yet attractive for potential investors. This project aims to assist the Government of [[Azerbaijan]] to overcome those barriers by reviewing and amending existing legal and institutional frameworks. The implementation of this project will be a significant step in contributing to achievement of the [[Millennium Development Goals]] in Azerbaijan.{{cite web | url= http://www.un-az.org/undp/xeberler.php?article_id=22773239&page=0407&lang=eng | title= Official website of UNDP in Azerbaijan |accessdate=2011-05-23}} A new wind plan called Yeni Yashma was built by Agency in 2015. Its capacity was to generate 50 MW. The plant is expected to be put into service by the end of this year.{{Cite news|url=https://azernews.az/business/87082.html|title=New wind plant under test in Azerbaijan|date=2015-08-24|work=AzerNews.az|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}} Azerbaijan plans to use the windy [[Caspian Sea]] in order to expand its alternative energy potential. Wind farms will be built offshore in an area marked by great winds. Nowadays the total capacity of power generation in the country is 7.2 thousand megawatts. Azerbaijan is able to produce about 24 billion kilowatt-hours and export 2.1 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity every year. There are tariffs for alternative energy depending on the region in Azerbaijan.{{Cite news|url=https://azernews.az/business/88958.html|title=Azerbaijan to build solar power plant in Germany|date=2015-10-21|work=AzerNews.az|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}} == Investments == Since 2000, approximately 800 million manats have been invested in this sphere. According to statistics, 9 per cent of the electricity generated in Azerbaijan in 2011 came from renewable sources, nearly entirely from [[Hydroelectricity|hydro-electric power]].{{Cite news|url=http://visions.az/en/news/505/d6381a45/|title=Renewable Energy for Oil-Rich Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|work=Visions of Azerbaijan Magazine|access-date=2018-06-30|language=ru-RU}} In 2014 the volume of investments made in the development of the [[alternative energy]] sphere in Azerbaijan reached 63.6 million manat. The majority of this volume, nearly 34.9 million manat, was allocated to the development of the [[solar energy]] sphere, another 28.7 million manat went toward [[wind power]]. The public fund of Azerbaijan invested 127 million manats in the development of alternative and renewable energy sources. The total capacity of alternative and renewable energy sources in the country is more than 12,000 megawatts. 4,500 MW of them fall on wind energy, [[biomass]] – 1,500 MW, [[geothermal energy]] – 800 MW, 350 MW - small hydro power plants.{{Cite web|url=https://evwind.es/2014/11/03/renewable-energy-potential-exceeds-12000-mw-in-azerbaijan/48497|title=Renewable Energy potential exceeds 12,000 MW in Azerbaijan {{!}} REVE|website=evwind.es|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-30}} It’s planned to increase the share of alternative energy in total production to 20 percent by 2020. A third of them will come from the wind energy. It requires 6.7 billion USD of investment.{{Cite web|url=http://conventionventures.com/events.php?action=details&event_id=120|title=Convention Ventures.|website=conventionventures.com|language=pl|access-date=2018-06-30}} == Cooperation == Azerbaijan is supported by [[Germany]] in the development of wind power. Also, it’s planned to build a solar power plant in Germany in the near future. The capacity of the plant will be approximately 10 megawatts. Works in this domain go on in [[Turkey]] too. State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (SAARES) collaborates with [[United Nations Development Programme|United Nations Development Program.]]{{Cite web|url=http://dspace.bhos.edu.az/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/1065/Azerbaijan-Alternative-and-Renewable-Energy.pdf?sequence=1|title=UNDP and SAARES|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 2009, [[United States Agency for International Development|USAID]] assisted to develop a preferential tariff to speed the development of wind power in Azerbaijan. === Affiliated organizations === * AzAlternativEnerji LLC * AzGunTech LLC * Gobustan Polygon * Monitoring Center * AREA TechnoPark{{Cite web|url=https://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/energy/se/pp/gere/gere.2_Oct.2015/12.pm/2_Nazir.Ramazanov_AZ.pdf|title=Cooperation of SAARES|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == See also == {{Portal|Azerbaijan|Energy}} * [[Energy]] * [[Ministry of Energy (Azerbaijan)]] * [[Alternative energy]] * [[Renewable energy]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == Literature == State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (Azerbaijan){{Cite book|title=State Agency on Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources (Azerbaijan)|last=|first=|publisher=|year=2012|isbn=978-620-1-33397-0|location=Baku, Azerbaijan|pages=}} == External links == * [http://www.area.gov.az/ Official website of ABEMDA (SAARES)] * [http://greenazerbaijan.org Green Azerbaijan], additional information {{Ministries of Azerbaijan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ministry Of Industry And Energy (Azerbaijan)}} [[Category:Government agencies of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 2009]] [[Category:Renewable energy in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Alternative energy]] [[Category:Renewable energy]] [[az:Azərbaycan Respublikası Sənaye və Energetika Nazirliyi]]

{{redirect|STEVE|other uses|steve (disambiguation)}} [[File:Optical Steve.jpg|thumb|This image of Steve was taken August 17, 2015 at Little Bow Resort, AB, Canada. Photo by Elfie Hall.]] '''Steve''' is an [[Atmospheric optics|atmospheric optical phenomenon]] which appears as a purple and green light ribbon in the sky, formally discovered in 2017 by [[aurora]] watchers from [[Alberta|Alberta, Canada]]. According to Eric Donovan's analysis of satellite data from the [[European Space Agency]]'s [[Swarm (spacecraft)|Swarm]] mission, Steve is caused by a {{convert|25|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide ribbon of hot [[gas]]es at an altitude of {{convert|450|km|mi|abbr=on}}, with a temperature of {{convert|3000|C|K F|abbr=on}} and flowing at a speed of {{convert|6|km/s|mi/s|abbr=on}} (compared to {{convert|10|m/s|ft/s|abbr=on}} outside the ribbon). The phenomenon is not rare, but nobody had looked into it in detail prior to that.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencealert.com/introducing-steve-a-newly-discovered-light-in-the-sky|title=Introducing Steve - a Newly Discovered Astronomical Phenomenon|last=McRae|first=Mike|date=24 April 2017|work=ScienceAlert|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Observing_the_Earth/Swarm/When_Swarm_met_Steve|title=When Swarm Met Steve|last=|first=|date=21 April 2017|work=ESA|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://phys.org/news/2018-08-kind-aurora.html|title=New kind of aurora is not an aurora at all|last=American Geophysical Union|first=|date=20 August 2018|work=Physorg.com|access-date=2018-08-21}}</ref> In August 2018, researchers determined that the phenomenon's [[skyglow]] was not associated with [[Precipitation|particle precipitation]] ([[electron]]s or [[ion]]s) and, as a result, could be generated in the [[ionosphere]].<ref name="GRL-20180820" />
== Discovery and naming == The aurora watchers who first discovered Steve, members of a Facebook group called Alberta Aurora Chasers, initially attributed the phenomenon to a proton aurora and erroneously called them "proton arcs",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2017/04/Meet_Steve|title=Meet Steve|website=European Space Agency|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref> but when physics professor Eric Donovan from the [[University of Calgary]] saw the pictures, he suspected that was not the case, because proton auroras are not visible.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39686055|title=Aurora photographers find new night sky lights and call them Steve|last=|first=|date=23 April 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}}</ref> As he correlated the time and location of the phenomenon with [[Swarm (spacecraft)|Swarm]] satellite data, and Song Despins photo (not seen here) including GPS coordinates, the phenomenon was very clearly distinguished.<ref name=":0" />
One of the aurora watchers, photographer Chris Ratzlaff,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://collegecandy.com/2017/04/27/steve-aurora-alberta-chasers-celestial-photos-full-story/|title=Amateur Sky-Watchers Discover Celestial Phenomenon, Name It 'Steve'|date=24 April 2017|}}</ref> suggested the name "Steve" from [[Over the Hedge (film)|''Over the Hedge'']], an animated comedy movie from 2006, in which its characters chose that name for something unknown.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-04-24/new-light-phenomenon-called-steve-by-aurora-watchers/8466234|title=New atmospheric phenomenon named Steve discovered by aurora watchers|last=|first=|date=24 April 2017|work=ABC News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Reportage of the heretofore undescribed unusual "aurora" went [[viral phenomenon|viral]] as an example of [[citizen science]] on [[Aurorasaurus]].<ref name="Twitter and Citizen science">{{Cite web |url=http://www.gi.alaska.edu/Alaska-Science-Forum/citizen-science-meets-aurora |title=Citizen science meets the aurora |last=Rozell |first=Ned |date=2015-04-02 |website=University of Alaska Fairbanks Geophysical Institute}}</ref><ref name="STEVE">{{Cite web |url=http://blog.aurorasaurus.org/?p=449 |title=7 Things to Know About "STEVE" |date=2017-03-14 |website=Aurorasaurus}}</ref>
A scientist listening to Eric Donovan's presentation at the December, 2016, meeting of the American Geophysical Union suggested "Strong Thermal Emission Velocity Enhancement" as a [[backronym]] of STEVE,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.googply.com/2017/04/24/introducing-steve-a-newly-discovered-astronomical-phenomenon/|title=Introducing Steve – a newly discovered astronomical phenomenon|date=2017-04-24|website=Googply News|access-date=2017-04-25}}</ref> one which has since been adopted by the team at [[NASA Goddard Space Flight Center]] studying Steve.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2018/03/steve-auroras-identified-plasma/|title=Meet ‘Steve,’ a Totally New Kind of Aurora|date=2018-03-14|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref>
== Occurrence and cause == Steve can be spotted closer to the [[equator]] than the aurora,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/shortcuts/2018/mar/19/steve-mystery-purple-aura-rivals-northern-lights-alberta-canada-nasa|title='Steve': the mystery purple aurora that rivals the northern lights|last=Saner|first=Emine|date=2018-03-19|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> and as of March 2018 has been observed in the United Kingdom, Canada, Alaska, northern U.S. states and New Zealand. Steve appears as a very narrow arc extending for hundreds or thousands of miles, aligned east-west. Steve generally lasts for 20 minutes to an hour. As of March 2018, Steve has only been spotted in the presence of an aurora. Steve was not observed from October 2016 to February 2017, or from October 2017 to February 2018, leading [[NASA]] to believe that Steve may only appear in certain seasons.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2018/nasa-needs-your-help-to-find-steve-and-heres-how|title=NASA Needs Your Help to Find Steve and Here's How|last=Garner|first=Rob|date=2018-03-14|work=NASA|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en}}</ref>
A study published in March 2018 by Donovan, Ratzlaff, and other co-authors in the peer-reviewed journal ''[[Science Advances]]'' suggested that Steve accompanies a subauroral ion drift (SAID),<ref>{{Cite journal|last=MacDonald|first=Elizabeth A.|last2=Donovan|first2=Eric|last3=Nishimura|first3=Yukitoshi|last4=Case|first4=Nathan A.|last5=Gillies|first5=D. Megan|last6=Gallardo-Lacourt|first6=Bea|last7=Archer|first7=William E.|last8=Spanswick|first8=Emma L.|last9=Bourassa|first9=Notanee|date=2018-03-01|title=New science in plain sight: Citizen scientists lead to the discovery of optical structure in the upper atmosphere|url=http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/4/3/eaaq0030|journal=Science Advances|language=en|volume=4|issue=3|pages=eaaq0030|doi=10.1126/sciadv.aaq0030|doi-access=free|pmid=29546244|pmc=5851661|issn=2375-2548}}</ref> a fast-moving stream of extremely hot particles. Steve marks the first observed visual effect accompanying a SAID.<ref name=":1" /> In August 2018, researchers determined that the phenomenon's skyglow was not associated with particle precipitation (electrons or ions) and, as a result, could be generated in the [[ionosphere]].<ref name="GRL-20180820">{{cite journal |last1=Gallardo-Lacourt |first1=B. |last2=Liang |first2=J. |last3=Nishimura |first3=Y. |last4=Donovan |first4=E. |title=On the Origin of STEVE: Particle Precipitation or Ionospheric Skyglow? |date=20 August 2018 |journal=[[Geophysical Research Letters]] |doi=10.1029/2018GL078509 }}</ref>
== See also == {{commonscat|STEVEs (Northern Lights)}} {{wiktionary|STEVE}} * [[Space weather]] * [[Thermosphere]]
== References == <references />
== External links == * [https://livestream.com/ESA/earthexplorer2017/videos/152430872 Eric Donovan's presentation at 2017 ESA Earth Explorer Missions Science Meeting] (1:08:30 - 1:26:00) * [https://www.facebook.com/groups/AlbertaAuroraChasers/ Alberta Aurora Chasers] * {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wRHwGD-is9U|title=The Aurora Named Steve|author=NASA Goddard with [[Liz MacDonald]]|website=YouTube|date=14 March 2018}}

{{cleanup-reorganize|date=June 2017}} [[File:Tarpan - Jagannath Ghat - Kolkata 2012-10-15 0622.JPG|thumb|The ''Tarpan'' (Offering holy water to the manes) is being done at the Jagannath Ghat, [[Kolkata]], at end of the Pitru Paksha.|alt= Tarpan is being done at the Jagannath Ghat, Kolkata.]] '''Tarpaṇa''' ({{lang-sa|तर्पण}}, {{lang-kn|ತರ್ಪಣ}}) is a term in the Vedic practice which refers to an offering made to divine entities. It refers to the act of the offering as well as the substance used in the offering itself. Tilatarpana (तिलतर्पण, ತಿಲತರ್ಪಣ) is a different but associated term that is sometimes confused with Tarpana. Tilatarpana is a specific form of Tarpana involving [[libation]]s offered to the [[Pitrs]] (deceased ancestors) using water and sesame seeds during [[Pitru Paksha]] or as a death rite.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indian Hindu devotee performs "Tarpan"|publisher=Hindustan Times|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/Photos-India/Mahalaya2010/Article4-609581.aspx|date=Oct 2010|accessdate=2013-09-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141215091147/http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/Photos-India/Mahalaya2010/Article4-609581.aspx|archivedate=2014-12-15|df=}}</ref> [[File:Kosha Kushi (Double Spoon).jpg|thumb|'''Kosha Kushi''' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]: কোশা-কুশী) (Double Spoon) is use for puja. This Kosha Kushi is made of pure copper. Kosha Kushi is used for offer holy water to God and Goddess and also used for shradh tarpan puja. Kosha Kushi is an important ritual item used in the Tantric worship of the Divine Mother.]] (i) Tarpana means '''Arghya''', an offering. It is offered to all [[Deva (Hinduism)|devas]] as well as the [[Navagraha]]s whenever mula[[mantra]] is recited as [[japa]]. (ii) Instances of welcome Tarpana are: :(a) for [[Lakshmi]], “आर्द्रां ज्वलंतीम् तृप्ताम् तर्पयन्तीम् “ ''Ārdrāṁ jvalantīm tr̥ptām tarpayantīm'' ([[Śrī Sūkta]] 4), "One who is satisfied and who satisfies those who offer Her Tarpana"{{cn|date=April 2015}} :(b) for [[Tripura Sundari]], “बिंदु तर्पण संतुष्टाम् पूर्वजा त्रिपुराम्बिका” ''bindu tarpaṇa santuṣṭām pūrvajā tripurāmbikā'' (''[[Lalita Sahasranama]]'' 178, 974), "One who is satisfied by just a single drop of Tarpana"{{cn|date=April 2015}}
(iii) Cow's milk (raw, unheated, and unpasteurized), water, sugar, saffron, cardamom, borneo-camphor, etc. are mixed and used as the offering according to the requirements.
(iv) One Tarpana (or Arghya) is offered for the recitation of every ten moolamantras and one for part thereof.
==Tilatarpana==
(i) Tilatarpana is the Tarpana (or Arghya) offered to Pitrus (departed ancestors) by male descendants who do not have a living father.
(ii) This is offered at the first annual [[Śrāddha|shraddha]] (death anniversary) and during subsequent annual shraddhas, [[amavasya]]s (new moon days), sankramanas (solar ingresses), eclipses, and during visits to selected holy places of pilgrimage...
(iii) Method of offering Tilatarpana: :(a) Black til seeds (gingelly seeds which are black and white which is eaten with jaggerry on makar sankrati usually on January 14th/15th in whole of north India but only black gingelly is used in Tarpana, not the sesame which is wrongly referred as Til are used along with water as the offering. :(b) The yagnopavita (sacred thread) is to be worn in the opposing position (i.e., on the right shoulder, which is termed as prAchInAvIti, प्राचीनावीति or apsabhya in Sanskrit). :(c) A pavitra (ring) made of kush grass should be worn on the ring finger of the right hand and kush grasses in left fingers horizontally called tekusha .
==Posture of hand while offering Tarpana== The posture of hand while offering Tarpana varies for offerings made to devas (Gods, Goddesses and Navagrahas), rishis (sages) and pitrus (departed ancestors). :(a) For devas, the offering is made to flow over the four fingers of the right hand other than the thumb. :(b) For rishis, the offering is made to flow on the area of the left side of the right palm between the wrist and the little finger. :(c) For the pitrus, the offering is made to flow over the right side of the right palm and the thumb of the right hand.
==Reasons for using (Gingelly) for Tarpana==
Gingelly is not to be confused with Sesame which is from large tree; Gingellyis a small seed storing energy and hence considered a favorite of all [[Deva (Hinduism)|Devas]], [[Shani]] (Saturn) and pitrus. [[Ganesha|Lord Ganesha]] is commonly offered pancha-kajjaya, a delicacy made using sesame. [[Shiva|Lord Shiva]] is worshipped with sesame seeds (tilakshata). For [[Vishnu|Lord Vishnu]], [[Brahma|Lord Brahma]], [[Laxmi|Goddess Laxmi]] and [[Saraswati|Goddess Saraswati]], Gingelly seeds are used in any of their favorite eatables and offered to bestow their special favors on the worshippers. Besides, it is used as a homa dravya (an ingredient in the fire offerings) in many [[Havanam|havans]] and [[Homa (ritual)|homas]]. Therefore, tila (Gingelly) and tilatarpana should not be decried as inauspicious.
==Reasons for offering Tarpana==
It is believed that one’s pitrus will be eagerly awaiting for tarpana on all the above-mentioned occasions. If no offering is made, they will return to their places disappointed, and the descendant misses their blessings which he would have received, if he had performed his filial duties.
